document.title: New York state intermediate science curriculum

479F908611E24D9385AA50CFAB6542F9.description:
Substances enter the atmosphere naturally and from human activity. Some of these
substances include dust from volcanic eruptions and greenhouse gases such as carbon
dioxide, methane, and water vapor. These substances can affect weather, climate, and
living things.

FA1FC448329A4EB6A4595B98F072EB59.description:
Hazardous weather conditions include thunderstorms, tornadoes, hurricanes, ice
storms, and blizzards. Humans can prepare for and respond to these conditions if given
sufficient warning

EEE65FD8C3D24ADE83D44A6E1255D6CD.description:
High-pressure systems generally bring fair weather. Low-pressure systems usually
bring cloudy, unstable conditions. The general movement of highs and lows is from
west to east across the United States.

3FCC020FD1DC42DF993C3EB80CA8CDCC.description:
Fronts are boundaries between air masses. Precipitation is likely to occur at these
boundaries.

CBE59F8F4EE148F9887E7BB647475AF5.description: The movement of air masses is determined by prevailing winds and upper air currents.

FE0DAC439418420EAE7F77348FA86F4E.description: Most local weather condition changes are caused by movement of air masses

53771263597442DC95C92A1E6D4C3771.description:
Air masses form when air remains nearly stationary over a large section of Earth’s
surface and takes on the conditions of temperature and humidity from that location.
Weather conditions at a location are determined primarily by temperature, humidity,
and pressure of air masses over that location

B8CDB76F096044E1A6F19C6E978B7F09.description: The uneven heating of Earth’s surface is the cause of weather

D3ACA2B6752F4B2DBA4A2C18518DD8C8.description:
Climate is the characteristic weather that prevails from season to season and year
to year.

F4A12DA4DD3A47A08AADA15DEA5C6D5A.description:
Weather describes the conditions of the atmosphere at a given location for a short
period of time

8E7F4489A31C4E70A46D975983F8E651.description:
The rock cycle model shows how types of rock or rock material may be transformed
from one type of rock to another.

D69D8F11FA4F425A9D7393839DC35B0D.description:
Rocks are classified according to their method of formation. The three classes of
rocks are sedimentary, metamorphic, and igneous. Most rocks show characteristics that
give clues to their formation conditions.

AB0B875DAAB4468F9F1C3854E6CCAF28.description:
Plates may collide, move apart, or slide past one another. Most volcanic activity
and mountain building occur at the boundaries of these plates, often resulting in earthquakes.

C85C18B50AA44972842CA5105719E4AE.description:
The Theory of Plate Tectonics explains how the “solid” lithosphere consists of a
series of plates that “float” on the partially molten section of the mantle. Convection
cells within the mantle may be the driving force for the movement of the plates

2ECBFBBF3F8B4DB3A5C8697DD9092B81.description:
Continents fitting together like puzzle parts and fossil correlations provided initial
evidence that continents were once together.

D697B7D0659F4111B55C44C00761FE3E.description: Folded, tilted, faulted, and displaced rock layers suggest past crustal movement

0CA6FBDE673F4E0790A4014956360C99.description:
Analysis of earthquake wave data (vibrational disturbances) leads to the conclusion
that there are layers within Earth. These layers—the crust, mantle, outer core, and
inner core—have distinct properties.

FCDEEB8C886E494FBF873D60EB282D8D.description:
The interior of Earth is hot. Heat flow and movement of material within Earth
cause sections of Earth’s crust to move. This may result in earthquakes, volcanic
eruption, and the creation of mountains and ocean basins.

5C1CA771949341C9B85115ACE6204E59.description: Describe volcano and earthquake patterns, the rock cycle, and weather and climate changes.

96FDD21052844A73A9EB3008122BEF73.description:
Water circulates through the atmosphere, lithosphere, and hydrosphere in what is
known as the water cycle.

F9E0192E75CE4FCAA8C4E7CB4C439865.description:
Erosion is the transport of sediment. Gravity is the driving force behind erosion.
Gravity can act directly or through agents such as moving water, wind, and glaciers.

E9C44416D7AA46749EA3AC457EDFA5BC.description:
The process of weathering breaks down rocks to form sediment. Soil consists of
sediment, organic material, water, and air.

D0D94B776ABF4AE9A0CC1317EA327464.description:
The dynamic processes that wear away Earth’s surface include weathering and
erosion.

E50879EAE8374DF5A7468F5B99AEE9A8.description:
Fossils are usually found in sedimentary rocks. Fossils can be used to study past
climates and environments.

5FCA822274E74CFD96D7EDD4ADDF1E66.description:
Rocks are composed of minerals. Only a few rock-forming minerals make up most
of the rocks of Earth. Minerals are identified on the basis of physical properties such as
streak, hardness, and reaction to acid.

C8A828097D784227900DC1A04B4857C7.description:
The majority of the lithosphere is covered by a relatively thin layer of water called
the hydrosphere

7089AEF847804089927D63F710F610BF.description: As altitude increases, air pressure decreases.

8D34801538E3413C92276EB8D026C2B1.description: As altitude increases, air pressure decreases.

17B560A77DC246F88C41DBBC98B0B876.description:
Nearly all the atmosphere is confined to a thin shell surrounding Earth. The atmosphere
is a mixture of gases, including nitrogen and oxygen with small amounts of water
vapor, carbon dioxide, and other trace gases. The atmosphere is stratified into layers,
each having distinct properties. Nearly all weather occurs in the lowest layer of the
atmosphere.

3CEC10248A8649FDA6ED0E0EBE40E493.description:
Explain how the atmosphere (air), hydrosphere (water), and lithosphere (land) interact, evolve,
and change.

0CFA625D11414371871C856ED355556B.description:
Students should develop an understanding of Earth as a set of closely coupled systems. The concept of systems
provides a framework in which students can investigate three major interacting components: lithosphere, hydrosphere,
and atmosphere. Processes act within and among the three components on a wide range of time scales to
bring about continuous change in Earth’s crust, oceans, and atmosphere.

D9060867AECE41E9B4735F424BEA0EDF.description:
Many of the phenomena that we observe on Earth involve interactions among components of air, water, and
land.

CD690C71DF81422A98A2D976FC06EA5E.description: The shape of Earth, the other planets, and stars is nearly spherical.

E24918FB8D0946B6B65DF7DF0B450577.description:
The tilt of Earth’s axis of rotation and the revolution of Earth around the Sun cause
seasons on Earth. The length of daylight varies depending on latitude and season.

951B70C4E8714B329165D9474264AA2C.description:
The apparent motions of the Sun, Moon, planets, and stars across the sky can be
explained by Earth’s rotation and revolution. Earth’s rotation causes the length of one
day to be approximately 24 hours. This rotation also causes the Sun and Moon to appear
to rise along the eastern horizon and to set along the western horizon. Earth’s revolution
around the Sun defines the length of the year as 365 1/4 days

FDF5F00052A549F68352B2803D4804DE.description:
Moons are seen by reflected light. Our Moon orbits Earth, while Earth orbits the
Sun. The Moon’s phases as observed from Earth are the result of seeing different portions
of the lighted area of the Moon’s surface. The phases repeat in a cyclic pattern in
about one month.

CA5779265A5948018A885C4B5EECB1B8.description:
The latitude/longitude coordinate system and our system of time are based on
celestial observations.

B4C90B78383C4E9C9EF81786DE7FE625.description:
Most objects in the solar system have a regular and predictable motion. These
motions explain such phenomena as a day, a year, phases of the Moon, eclipses, tides,
meteor showers, and comets.

EBA08B14E3E2431AA2EE3B2A38F85112.description:
Gravity is the force that keeps planets in orbit around the Sun and the Moon in
orbit around the Earth.

16845AD4D6734CFA89E8E3C900D855D0.description:
The Sun and the planets that revolve around it are the major bodies in the solar system.
Other members include comets, moons, and asteroids. Earth’s orbit is nearly circular.

E226EF3BDB114619AB05D042C9FB4750.description:
Other stars are like the Sun but are so far away that they look like points of light.
Distances between stars are vast compared to distances within our solar system.

EEAD2672C0C048A2801F5CA6EB3F2AB6.description:
Earth’s Sun is an average-sized star. The Sun is more than a million times greater
in volume than Earth.

03BBC258749147FDA47F04E7211F7168.description: Explain daily, monthly, and seasonal changes on Earth.

BB6633B02F194FE8A55D766E4ADAC3FC.description:
The universe is comprised of a wide array of objects, a few of which can be seen by the unaided eye. Others can
only be observed with scientific instruments. These celestial objects, distinct from Earth, are in motion relative to
Earth and each other. Measurements of these motions vary with the perspective of the observer. Cyclical changes
on Earth are caused by interactions among objects in the universe.

7ABAB7951F7C48A28A94F02081E39D89.description: The Earth and celestial phenomena can be described by principles of relative motion and perspective

F682635A5838420898ED9B6DA1B268D1.description: The Physical Setting:The Earth and celestial phenomena can be described by principles of relative motion and perspective

4EA99FA0EA3145F6971C6E0117C31ACC.description: determine the volume of a regular- and an irregular-shaped solid, using water displacement

8E4B75930A9545E69B253102315506CC.description: determine the density of liquids, and regular- and irregular-shaped solids

2FE6CF7895774D9ABD4632794AA41912.description: measure weather variables such as wind speed and direction, relative humidity, barometric pressure, etc.

A59774FF130143DEA3EE3200F4EB58C9.description: predict the characteristics of an air mass based on the origin of the air mass

D7D98AD7338E4955A2A4BE0395142BC5.description: generate and interpret field maps including topographic and weather maps

1A8EFD61E7C044CB9783C2521AA87405.description: measure the angular elevation of an object, using appropriate instruments

E335602CCE3A46F4B9DF16FAD89CAA1A.description: use a magnetic compass to find cardinal directions

B33879EA867A4FC69DB76408B7CCFA88.description: plot the location of recent earthquake and volcanic activity on a map and identify patterns of distribution

43DC26AFF799449EAEE588A90CE0E31E.description:
use a diagram of the rock cycle to determine geological processes that led to the formation of a specific rock
type

FB23B90D2221453CACC36BEC9C3FB27A.description: using identification tests and a flow chart, identify mineral samples

1C39CEF5DC7F439787D2BE60E54146A8.description:
given the latitude and longitude of a location, indicate its position on a map and determine the latitude and
longitude of a given location on a map

2FCB1ED0435241AC8649C126B9F17F4A.description: develop and use a dichotomous key

6FBC70D4CED54F1D8D76FBB12B7C9B52.description: classify objects according to an established scheme and a student-generated scheme

55705D15EAA04085B69E4788D38E5F6D.description: recognize and analyze patterns and trends

3382F16CDEEC47C5944F5401A16B4047.description: use appropriate units for measured or calculated values

560933113C9C49E59380D52B8734F5ED.description:
safely and accurately use the following measurement tools:
• metric ruler
• balance
• stopwatch
• graduated cylinder
• thermometer
• spring scale
• voltmeter

7A125F97667745B1B6726B4430FAD61D.description: follow safety procedures in the classroom and laboratory

0BA870543FA947B8AAB9378D9D8B8C7C.description:
Students participate in an extended, culminating mathematics, science, and technology
project. The project would require students to:
• Working Effectively: Contributing to the work of a brainstorming group, laboratory
partnership, cooperative learning group, or project team; planning procedures;
identify and managing responsibilities of team members; and staying on
task, whether working alone or as part of a group.
• Gathering and Processing Information: Accessing information from printed
media, electronic data bases, and community resources and using the information
to develop a definition of the problem and to research possible solutions.
• Generating and Analyzing Ideas: Developing ideas for proposed solutions,
investigating ideas, collecting data, and showing relationships and patterns in
the data.
• Common Themes: Observing examples of common unifying themes, applying
them to the problem, and using them to better understand the dimensions of the
problem.
• Realizing Ideas: Constructing components or models, arriving at a solution,
and evaluating the result.
• Presenting Results: Using a variety of media to present the solution and to
communicate the results.

80ABD72E536144B1B302D60A96899223.description:
Solving interdisciplinary problems involves a variety of skills and strategies, including
effective work habits; gathering and processing information; generating and analyzing
ideas; realizing ideas; making connections among the common themes of mathematics,
science, and technology; and presenting results.

4A72866F1CEE4FAAABB1979D6088B560.description:
Describe and explain phenomena by designing and conducting investigations
involving systematic observations, accurate measurements, and the identification
and control of variables; by inquiring into relevant mathematical ideas; and by using
mathematical and technological tools and procedures to assist in the investigation.

BD5891931D5545DA9E0336E724566B4D.description:
Design solutions to real-world problems of general social interest related to home,
school, or community using scientific experimentation to inform the solution and
applying mathematical concepts and reasoning to assist in developing a solution.

85C8DBB0F9EB4E89AE4BB1866653B704.description:
Make informed consumer decisions by seeking answers to appropriate questions
about products, services, and systems; determining the cost/benefit and risk/benefit
tradeoffs; and applying this knowledge to a potential purchase

A07CA08F7AB241398F2C7DD2B05CA8F1.description:
Analyze science/technology/society problems and issues at the local level and
plan and carry out a remedial course of action.

0E56E83150C847D7919A513D71E19178.description:
The knowledge and skills of mathematics, science, and technology are used together to
make informed decisions and solve problems, especially those relating to issues of science/technology/society,
consumer decision making, design, and inquiry into
phenomena

C6FB8DF0ADA54F708CEFFA0280434002.description:
—Interdisciplinary Problem Solving
Students will apply the knowledge and thinking skills of mathematics, science, and technology to address real-life
problems and make informed decisions.

32ED4139ED064493B36F62C40142DA9E.description:
Use graphs of information for a decision-making problem to determine the optimum
solution.

DD646FE8B930420B89ABB0DE000A68F2.description:
Determine the criteria and constraints and make trade-offs to determine the best
decision.

FCAD975DF1D74473AE57C006D5756400.description:
In order to arrive at the best solution that meets criteria within constraints, it is often necessary
to make trade-offs

EE8147CBD7FC43C09E93B1C7FFE00269.description:
Observe patterns of change in trends or cycles and make predictions on what
might happen in the future.

5066B3BD0B5647A196FA9E4B19E3ED0F.description: Use simple linear equations to represent how a parameter changes with time.

ADAA5DAD998A4AA3967217727D5745F9.description:
Identifying patterns of change is necessary for making predictions about future
behavior and conditions.

15DF5F35A8AE47CE84F3FE7875A2CECD.description:
Describe changes within equilibrium cycles in terms of frequency or cycle length
and determine the highest and lowest values and when they occur.

2675C04914EC414BA4253B1DC9A9D70B.description:
Describe how feedback mechanisms are used in both designed and natural systems
to keep changes within desired limits

323322B2D68E4E49A047DFF90EE706D7.description:
Equilibrium is a state of stability due either to a lack of change (static equilibrium) or a
balance between opposing forces (dynamic equilibrium).

6AC352C0BDFA4615ADBC706E9A66513B.description: Use powers of ten notation to represent very small and very large numbers.

C51571734DA54B099B2C1A84DD1AC729.description:
Cite examples of how different aspects of natural and designed systems change at
different rates with changes in scale.

A34BFA621F3C45DF9826EC9121E96733.description:
The grouping of magnitudes of size, time, frequency, and pressures or other units of
measurement into a series of relative order provides a useful way to deal with the
immense range and the changes in scale that affect the behavior and design of systems.

29AEBAD6D63E478796ACCB6B4ECEB5E2.description:
Demonstrate the effectiveness of different models to represent the same thing and
the same model to represent different things

0B8F80B508FC4E888E476E081D12E2F7.description:
Use models to study processes that cannot be studied directly (e.g., when the real
process is too slow, too fast, or too dangerous for direct observation)

9C687F0E1E29447197F0F8C097FB9A62.description:
Select an appropriate model to begin the search for answers or solutions to a question
or problem.

BFCB656CBB634FD3A497675193FB3D7C.description:
Models are simplified representations of objects, structures, or systems used in analysis,
explanation, interpretation, or design.

CD505338D9CD41A3A09DFA3706A95649.description:
Describe how the output from one part of a system (which can include material,
energy, or information) can become the input to other parts.

08AF4DF9AC8D4E84B16E3429A238E108.description: Describe the differences between open- and closed-loop systems.

144B3A74E26840B5AD20D9F0AD4AA7C2.description:
Describe the differences and similarities among engineering systems, natural systems,
and social systems.

F97960F9E9074D10BE86F5842639ADDA.description: Describe the differences between dynamic systems and organizational systems

093A4F130B97499499B6634C837734B3.description:
Through systems thinking, people can recognize the commonalities that exist among all
systems and how parts of a system interrelate and combine to perform specific
functions.

02416FBF48D644418931726DE6B412A7.description:
Interconnectedness: Common Themes: Students will understand the relationships and common themes that connect mathematics, science, and technology
and apply the themes to these and other areas of learning.

1B83263BB03B4B81A4E8F6458CE616C1.description:
Explain the impact of the use and abuse of electronically generated information on
individuals and families

334895B7E01B449FA35C4566EF7AE301.description:
Describe applications of information technology in mathematics, science, and
other technologies that address needs and solve problems in the community.

B833BAF7922D4568B36D092B52B5E5AA.description:
Use graphical, statistical, and presentation software to present projects to fellow
classmates.

4D96809BB56B426DBC696A1D27F306F4.description:
Information technology can have positive and negative impacts on society, depending
upon how it is used.

985EEF1A906548F0B66353B12CE9AA12.description:
Understand why electronically stored personal information has greater potential
for misuse than records kept in conventional form.

5902BDBC403040389BA215AF5375DFC3.description: Identify advantages and limitations of data-handling programs and graphics programs.

3CA88845011F4B7DB153078C547A97DB.description: identify and explain sources of error in a data collection

A1AF8FD2B7114D3894F0148FB6D4F89C.description: critically analyze data to exclude erroneous information

FFE6C06544DE43D19E3EC0BFE4BC9AD0.description:
Understand the need to question the accuracy of information displayed on a computer
because the results produced by a computer may be affected by incorrect
data entry.

C99C492A132A41AB8F7B761F61AC2384.description:
Knowledge of the impacts and limitations of information systems is essential to its effectiveness
and ethical use.

B09D81E5722E41F0ACBCB2967D40F817.description: Use simple modeling programs to make predictions.

9B6701519CAD448D95A4CFE578B24734.description: use the collected data to communicate a scientific concept

624B543B44044DAB8016916B096103FF.description: collect the data, using the appropriate, available tool

2915C9BC87AA46EA9F0D87296704E733.description: Collect data from probes to measure events and phenomena.

7E1CFE326C5C4B4C95D138A1A6A01712.description:
Systematically obtain accurate and relevant information pertaining to a particular
topic from a range of sources, including local and national media, libraries, museums,
governmental agencies, industries, and individuals

AA49F43C210D4815A6B817058DBA910F.description:
Use spreadsheets and database software to collect, process, display, and analyze
information. Students access needed information from electronic databases and
on-line telecommunication services

505764B8ACD946D095AB43583A2AA48C.description:
Use a range of equipment and software to integrate several forms of information in
order to create good-quality audio, video, graphic, and text-based presentations.

56EF2B5FE86C42D9BBAC7268D15B23D1.description:
Information technology is used to retrieve, process, and communicate information as a
tool to enhance learning

A1087E586F6F4030B990DF952C10A466.description: Information Systems:Students will access, generate, process, and transfer information, using appropriate technologies.

1C1D2349681B48619B8B707B5A0315E3.description:
In a group setting, test their solution against design specifications, present and
evaluate results, describe how the solution might have been modified for different or
better results, and discuss trade-offs that might have to be made.

FE9ED72DA75840AD8A61F73B16A40C56.description: construct a model of the product or process

1E5D9E271FFE4B28A6AAC906DEAA32CF.description: design and construct a model of the product or process

5A14D827C638483EA5A7CC3262743F86.description:
Develop plans, including drawings with measurements and details of construction,
and construct a model of the solution, exhibiting a degree of craftsmanship.

D645BC6F4D3648CE9073983C1A813DD0.description: evaluate alternatives based on the constraints of design

233196853BC04608B3C15D71E97211BC.description:
Consider constraints and generate several ideas for alternative solutions, using
group and individual ideation techniques (group discussion, brainstorming, forced
connections, role play); defer judgment until a number of ideas have been generated;
evaluate (critique) ideas; and explain why the chosen solution is optimal.

0FB6772FF9E54F16B5AB091F22441E26.description:
use all available information systems for a preliminary search that
addresses the need

E04A3EE18DE1432A87DD7075BF53DE27.description:
Locate and utilize a range of printed, electronic, and human information resources
to obtain ideas

225DD7F407964DEBAE2720BB3D3BDB9D.description:
identify a scientific or human need that is subject to a technological solution
which applies scientific principles

5D1035CAA32440399298AEB857EA2DFF.description:
Identify needs and opportunities for technical solutions from an investigation of
situations of general or social interest.

5B4BDF6DFA4742A5B8C056D7E62DD5BA.description:
Engineering design is an iterative process involving modeling and optimization (finding
the best solution within given constraints); this process is used to develop technological
solutions to problems within given constraints.

EDCACFCA06A74E2D985D030145BAC95E.description:
Modify their personal understanding of phenomena based on evaluation of their
hypothesis.

3A38D1DC18CE49AB9E64AEC29E21E5C1.description: use and interpret graphs and data tables

D37406BC28224E24B979EA35B5A11B41.description: suggest improvements and recommendations for further studying

BE4B381042B4414EBA0E213AEB3BD86C.description: make predictions based on experimental data

9B4730CCF5AD4CC28EA79CE04EEEDC6F.description:
form and defend a logical argument about cause-and-effect relationships
in an investigation

7AE866DB429544D58B5DA0A1DE046EFD.description:
formulate and defend explanations and conclusions as they relate to
scientific phenomena

70E41B67B5C54CB99C83CC0E7CFFEBA5.description: evaluate the original hypothesis in light of the data

915E099BED524E5FB5AE29C7FDBDAB63.description: identify sources of error and the limitations of data collected

52CD9F0AB19F43948B1D7D20A90D69AF.description: accurately describe the procedures used and the data gathered

1505F2B31BD8434C9ED36545206AC075.description:
Interpret the organized data to answer the research question or hypothesis and to
gain insight into the problem

36BCF53581CD438E8B0B08B5214F47DC.description: generate and use scales, create legends, and appropriately label axes

1038AF041A8F47AFAC2EE67A9A8CD312.description:
organize results, using appropriate graphs, diagrams, data tables, and
other models to show relationships

E2D9A17EC6CC4CB4997FBDD91CC8E7D6.description:
Design charts, tables, graphs, and other representations of observations in conventional
and creative ways to help them address their research question or hypothesis.

144DEB4B052040788EF90B7E4C3ADC55.description:
The observations made while testing proposed explanations, when analyzed using conventional
and invented methods, provide new insights into phenomena.

108D874FD95149EDB39FFBF3CDC88DFA.description:
Carry out their research proposals, recording observations and measurements
(e.g., lab notes, audiotape, computer disk, videotape) to help assess the explanation.

791AC2B690DB45F9903CCEB4370D093A.description: choose appropriate sample size and number of trials

AEA7979F776C49DBBB3BB38BA3047A39.description:
identify independent variables (manipulated), dependent variables
(responding), and constants in a simple controlled experiment

379E7960797848B096535A0A1DB849A3.description:
Develop, present, and defend formal research proposals for testing their own
explanations of common phenomena, including ways of obtaining needed observations
and ways of conducting simple controlled exp

21FD88DA77FD4DA896B2D4642E0B5B3B.description:
use appropriate tools and conventional techniques to solve problems
about the natural world, including:
• measuring
• observing
• describing
• classifying
• sequencing

54FA02F353544FA58224E1367CCED9EC.description: design and conduct an experiment to test a hypothesis

717051BAEA044DBF9A361D773638B58F.description: conduct an experiment designed by others

08829D4488BC4F46992D2B6EEFABEE44.description:
Use conventional techniques and those of their own design to make further observations
and refine their explanations, guided by a need for more information.

38330C921BE64DF1B19484A3DCF4DEBA.description:
Beyond the use of reasoning and consensus, scientific inquiry involves the testing of proposed
explanations involving the use of conventional techniques and procedures and usually
requiring considerable ingenuity

54F7E020F45948CD9FCE6675E0A1191A.description:
Seek to clarify, to assess critically, and to reconcile with their own thinking the
ideas presented by others, including peers, teachers, authors, and scientists.

5318CB2040434729A1F09D47EFDA0195.description:
Represent, present, and defend their proposed explanations of everyday observations
so that they can be understood and assessed by others.

BC027504BC504EC1A7CFD17303C3B221.description: differentiate among observations, inferences, predictions, and explanation

669E490774674BCF813EAA1EF303EB19.description: propose a model of a natural phenomenon

B415B90EEFFC483BBE819A044B4ACE3F.description:
Construct explanations independently for natural phenomena, especially by
proposing preliminary visual models of phenomena.

13BE570932CC496B968C6D03BC2228C5.description: refine and clarify questions so that they are subject to scientific investigation

4D414466FAB742C780647AA7AF261006.description: identify appropriate references to investigate a question

48045B679DEC4AC7B9B791846E1C135A.description:
Formulate questions independently with the aid of references appropriate for
guiding the search for explanations of everyday observations.

A092C33DD2634585BCF31957F78E5603.description:
The central purpose of scientific inquiry is to develop explanations of natural phenomena
in a continuing, creative process.

B41B89F885064B0E880EDFFCF8C17D3D.description: use appropriate scientific tools to solve problems about the natural world

2E83177A2E584B02A77B19ED7A2EC483.description:
Apply mathematical knowledge to solve real-world problems and problems that
arise from the investigation of mathematical ideas, using representations such as
pictures, charts, and tables.

7A384EAB421A47E3869028CD8CE64206.description: Critical thinking skills are used in the solution of mathematical problems

255CB0963A534073AF0C78A9F42DCF9B.description:
Use inductive reasoning to construct, evaluate, and validate conjectures and
arguments, recognizing that patterns and relationships can assist in explaining and
extending mathematical phenomena

A8CAF98A5A514C4987A0BF9BCE083971.description: Deductive and inductive reasoning are used to reach mathematical conclusions

B6D5B3A708FB4413860FFA718EB0DA88.description:
apply mathematical equations to describe relationships among variables in
the natural world

42EC372436414AF8AF4CC1224608BA5B.description:
identify relationships among variables including: direct, indirect, cyclic,
constant; identify non-related material

8639E6D4D54E493C838A80A5D40DBD60.description:
Extend mathematical notation and symbolism to include variables and algebraic
expressions in order to describe and compare quantities and express mathematical
relationships.

55E5CF2F84D345DEACCC2EBE33F7EB97.description: Abstraction and symbolic representation are used to communicate mathematically.

2FEDBD90773343EA97C1FD7CF72A2B49.description:
Analysis, Inquiry,
and Design:Students will use mathematical analysis, scientific inquiry, and engineering design, as appropriate, to pose
questions, seek answers, and develop solutions.
